1.1    Introduction



Pacific Gas and Electric Company (PG&E) operates the Gateway Generating Station (GGS), a nominal 530 megawatt (MW) natural gas-fired combined cycle electric power generating facility located in Antioch, California. The GGS uses aqueous ammonia in its selective catalytic reduction (SCR) system to reduce emissions of nitrogen oxides (NOX) to the atmosphere, as well as for condensate hydrogen ion content (pH) control. As the company responsible for operating GGS, PG&E takes its safety obligations in storing and using aqueous ammonia seriously. The following document describes what could happen if there were to be an accident, the steps PG&E takes every day to ensure a safely operating plant, and what to do in the event of an emergency.



1.2    Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies



PG&E's vision is to be the leading utility in the United States; to that effect, PG&E's values are presented below:

-    We act with integrity and communicate honestly and openly.

-    We are passionate about meeting our customers' needs and delivering for our shareholders.

-    We are accountable for all of our own actions; these include safety, protecting the environment, and supporting our communities.

-    We work together as a team and are committed to excellence and innovation.

-    We respect each other and celebrate our diversity.



The GGS accidental release prevention policy involves a unified approach that integrates proven technology, staff training on operation and maintenance practices, and tested management system practices. All applicable procedures of the State of California and the United States Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) regulatory programs are adhered to, including key elements such as training, systems management, and emergency response procedures.



As a supplier of energy to approximately 5 percent of Americans and more than 40 percent of Californians, we recognize that the choices we make about the way we produce and del

nd illness-free work environment for the benefit of our employees, our customers, and our communities. Our Safety and Health Policy forms the foundation for the programs PG&E uses to achieve this goal. This policy requires that employees do their jobs with the goal of creating a work and business environment free from injury, illness, and property damage for the benefit of employees, customers, and the general public; employees (1) perform work in a way that protects and promotes the safety and health of themselves, co-workers, and the public, and (2) comply with all applicable health and safety laws and regulations; and each officer effectively manages the occupational and public safety and health matters concerning business activities for which he or she is responsible.



GGS staff verify and improve the safety and environmental program by implementing the Risk Management Plan (RMP) prevention program requirements such as performing hazard reviews (HRs), maintaining current operating procedures, conducting training on the ammonia system, conducting compliance audits, and implementing procedures for process modifications. Manuals and procedures are available to employees at all times. The environmental, health, and safety program manuals at the GGS include the California Accidental Release Prevention (CalARP) Program RMP.



This document complies with the EPA Risk Management Program under Section 112(r) of the Clean Air Act (CAA) Amendments of 1990, Title 40 of the Code of Federal Regulations (CFR), Part 68, and the CalARP Program under Title 19 of the California Code of Regulations (CCR), Division 2, Chapter 4.5. This document summarizes our existing health and safety programs, our internal management response procedures, and ongoing actions that are designed to prevent or minimize impacts of accidental releases of ammonia to the environment. The GGS has also prepared an Emergency Action Plan to handle any potential accidental releases.



1.3    Facility Descripti

on and Regulated Substances Information



The GGS is located on Wilbur Avenue, in the City of Antioch, in Contra Costa County, California, on the southern shore of the San Joaquin River. Highway 4 and the Antioch Bridge are just east of the site. Immediately south and west of the site are existing industrial facilities. The river borders the north side, while a recreational marina, open space, and additional industrial land uses are present east of the site.



The GGS combined cycle power unit consists of two natural gas-fired combustion turbine generators, two heat recovery steam generators (HRSGs), and one steam turbine generator. In the combined cycle process, electricity is generated from the combustion turbines and the steam turbine. Each combustion turbine generator converts the thermal energy of the natural gas fuel to mechanical energy, which drives the electrical generator. At the same time, the thermal energy from the exhaust flue gas off the combustion turbines is directed to the HRSG to convert pressurized water into steam, which turns the steam turbine to drive the electricity generator. The facility also includes two 195-foot-tall exhaust stacks on the HRSGs, one air-cooled condenser system, a wet surface air cooler, storage tanks, a control building, electrical power transformers, and transmission facilities to interconnect the generated electricity to the power grid.



Aqueous ammonia is used in the GGS's SCR system to reduce NOX emissions and for condensate pH control. Up to 18,020 gallons of 29.4 percent aqueous ammonia solution (39,628 pounds of ammonia in solution) are present in the process at any given time.



The maximum quantity of aqueous ammonia stored and handled at the GGS exceeds the Risk Management Program and CalARP Program threshold quantities, but not the Process Safety Management (PSM) threshold quantities. Therefore, the aqueous ammonia process is subject to Risk Management Program and CalARP Program regulations, but not PSM re

quirements. The aqueous ammonia process is a Program 2 process.



1.4    Summary of the Accidental Release Prevention Program and Chemical-Specific Prevention Steps



Management System



Risk Management Program and CalARP Program regulations require those facilities with processes subject to Program 2 to develop a management system to oversee the implementation of the program elements. The management system has to be assigned to a qualified person or position that has the overall responsibility for the development, implementation, and integration of the RMP. PG&E has assigned the Plant Manager as the qualified person who has the overall responsibility for the development, implementation, and integration of the RMP. The Plant Manager is assisted by the Operations Supervisor, Plant Engineer, Maintenance Supervisor, and Environmental Compliance Manager in the implementation of the RMP.



In addition to the management system, the RMP and changes to it are communicated by supervisors to staff through normal day-to-day interactions, refresher training, and regular safety meetings. The Plant Manager, Plant Engineer, Operations Supervisor, Maintenance Supervisor, and Environmental Compliance Manager are the primary staff responsible for various elements of the RMP. Changes to the aqueous ammonia process are managed, reviewed, and communicated through the process modification procedures.



Chemical-Specific Prevention Steps



The prevention program elements described in the following section represent integrated administrative controls intended to ensure the safety of workers, the public, and the environment. The program elements such as HRs, compliance audits, and incident investigations result in the development of additional safeguards. In addition, this facility is staffed 24 hours per day, 365 days per year. Some of the safety features of the ammonia process are described below. Unless otherwise noted, the safeguards listed below have been installed as part of the or

iginal installation of the aqueous ammonia process.



Aqueous Ammonia Process



The aqueous ammonia storage tanks are enclosed within a walled containment basin that slopes to a centrally located, covered sump beneath the tanks that runs the length of the containment area. There is a walled containment pad under the tanker truck unloading facility that drains into the covered sump under the tanks.



Standby power needed for electrical systems, such as monitors and alarms, is provided by the Uninterruptible Power Supply System. Other safety features of the aqueous ammonia storage and unloading facility include:



-    Ammonia area monitoring system with audible and visible alarms, which monitor for ammonia releases

-    Eyewash and shower station in case of worker exposure to ammonia

-    Piping and connections for wash-down of containment basin with clean water

-    Permanent lighting to allow for safe working conditions during low-light conditions

-    Lightning protection to prevent damage from lightning

-    Truck barrier posts to protect ammonia tanks and delivery lines from vehicle damage

-    Liquid level indication and high-level alarm for each tank, easily visible from the unloading position

-    Tank level and pressure indicators and pressure relief valves and alarms in the plant Control Room

>    The indicators allow for monitoring of pressure and ammonia level in various vessels and prevent over-pressurization and overfilling.

>    The pressure relief valves are designed to release excess pressure, preventing a catastrophic failure of the vessels.

-    Shut-off valves located on the tank fill lines, which automatically close if the emergency high-level alarm is triggered

-    Local manual controls for all pumps to allow operators to shut down

-    Vacuum breaker valves on each tank to prevent backflow into the tank



Safety equipment (for two personnel) includes: two rescue breathers, face shields, non-vented chemical goggles, two pairs of ammonia-resistant gloves, two pairs o

f ammonia-resistant hoods, two pairs of ammonia-resistant pants and jacket/slicker, one first aid kit, and one fire extinguisher.



Area sensors are located in the ammonia unloading and storage facility and injection skid to monitor for ambient ammonia concentrations. Alarms are designed to warn staff of ammonia releases and annunciate in the Control Room with local audible sound.



Prevention Program Elements



The GGS accidental release prevention program is based on the following key elements:

-    Detailed management system and clear levels of responsibilities and team member roles

-    Comprehensive safety process information that is readily available to staff, emergency responders, and contractors

-    Comprehensive preventive maintenance (PM) program

-    A HR of equipment and procedures with operations and maintenance (O&M) staff participation

-    Use of state-of-the-art process and safety equipment

-    Use of accurate and effective operating procedures, written with O&M staff participation

-    High level of training of O&M staff

-    Implementation of an incident investigation, inspection, and auditing program using qualified staff



For the aqueous ammonia process, the prevention program contains the following elements: 



Safety Information 

Hazard Review 

Operating Procedures 

Training

Maintenance 

Compliance Audits 

Incident Investigation



1.5    Five-Year Accident History Summary



The Risk Management Program and CalARP Program regulations require reporting the five-year accident history of the covered process. The details of accidental releases are required for accidents that have caused at least one of the following:



-    Onsite deaths, injuries, or significant property damage

-    Known offsite deaths, injuries, property damage, environmental damage, evacuations, or sheltering in place



There have been no accidents involving aqueous ammonia at the GGS in the last five years.



1.6    Emergency Response Program Summary



GGS has established a written em

ergency action program that is followed by the employees to help safely control accidental releases of hazardous substances. Risk Management Program regulations require that an Emergency Action Plan be prepared for facilities that are not responding facilities. The plan must be prepared in accordance with the provisions of 8 CCR Section 3220. The Emergency Action Plan described in this section is for facilities with employees who are not responders to emergency situations. 



GGS's Emergency Action Plan is submitted with the revised CalARP RMP to Contra Costa Health Services (CCHS) for review and comment to ensure that it is consistent with the Contra Costa County Emergency Response Area Plan. Changes to this plan, including updated emergency contact information, are otherwise coordinated with CCHS and the Contra Costa County Fire Protection District at least once per year. The names and contact information of individuals involved in the coordination activities, as well as the date and a description of coordination activities, are documented.



The Contra Costa Hazardous Materials Programs (CCHMP) Incident Response Team is the designated primary response agency for the GGS. PG&E has ongoing emergency response coordination activities with the following agencies:

-    CCHMP

-    Contra Costa County Fire Protection District

-    Contra Costa County Sheriff's Department

-    Sutter Delta Medical Center



PG&E has a signed agreement with Sutter Delta Medical Center and Contra Costa County Fire Protection District to receive customary and appropriate emergency assistance in the event of emergency.



PG&E conducted an ammonia release response drill with the Contra Costa County Fire Protection District, CCHMP, Airgas, and neighboring facility (NRG) on December 14, 2010. PG&E also conducted a Table Top Ammonia Emergency Response Exercise with CCHS on December 3, 2014. Beginning in 2024, GGS will also begin conducting annual exercises of its emergency notification procedures.

The Plant Manager shall be responsible for implementing the Emergency Action Plan, and for reviewing and updating the program at least every three years. The Plant Manager is also responsible for maintaining up-to-date emergency contact information. The Environmental Compliance Manager shall be responsible for scheduling and coordinating training of the personnel according to the requirements of the Emergency Action Plan. The Plant Manager can provide additional information regarding the contents of the Emergency Action Plan.

The Plant Manager is responsible for the safety and security of all plant personnel, contractors, visitors, and equipment. The Plant Manager is also responsible for reviewing and approving the Emergency Action Plan.



1.7    Planned Changes to Improve Safety



A number of studies and inspections have been conducted to improve the safety of the aqueous ammonia process at the GGS. The most recent HR of the aqueous ammonia process was conducted in October 2017. A seismic assessment was also conducted in October 2017.



During these studies and inspections, no risk reduction measures were recommended because existing safeguards were thought to adequately mitigate risk associated with potential accident

al releases of aqueous ammonia. However, recommendations were made for correcting several inconsistencies in how the design and operation of the aqueous ammonia system are documented. Those recommendations are currently being assessed by GGS personnel for implementation, as appropriate. No additional changes are currently planned to improve safety of the aqueous ammonia system.



Details of the recommendations from the most recent HR, as mentioned above, can be found in the action item tables attached with Section 6, Hazard Review, of this RMP. The GGS uses the action item tables developed for the HR to track progress and timely closure of action items from technical studies. The GGS also reports the number of recommended action items, the number of action items completed, and the number of action items in progress. Eighteen items were recommended for follow-up as a result of the most recent HR; GGS is in the process of determining and implementing resolutions to each of these recommended action items, as discussed with CCHS during a September 2020 audit.



In assessing action items/planned activities for resolution, GGS prioritizes their implementation by applying the policy of protecting firstly the personnel, secondly the environment, and thirdly the properties.
